G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28** (modification of custody and support) and **M.G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as this Court issued the original custody judgment and both parties reside within the Commonwealth.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28** (modification of custody and support) and **M.G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as this Court issued the original custody judgment and both parties reside within the Commonwealth.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: The Plaintiff, Jessica Collins, respectfully files this Complaint for Modification pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28 and c. 209C, § 20, seeking modification of the custody provisions contained in the existing Judgment of Divorce/Parenting Order entered on **May 14, 2019** by the Middlesex County Probate and Family Court.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The current custodial arrangement places **Samantha’s safety and emotional well‑being** at risk and no longer reflects her best interests, as defined under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 31** and **Yannas v. Frondistou–Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2013Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The current custodial arrangement places **Samantha’s safety and emotional well‑being** at risk and no longer reflects her best interests, as defined under **M.G.L. c. 208, § 31** and **Yannas v. Frondistou–Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2013Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: This case interprets G.L. c. 208, § 31 generally and sets out the ‘real advantage’/best‑interests framework for custody and removal, but it does not hold that a particular custodial arrangement placed a child’s safety or emotional well‑being at risk. In Yannas, the Supreme Judicial Court affirmed the existing custodial arrangement (physical custody with the mother and removal to Greece) as being in the children’s best interests; it did not find the arrangement harmful or inadequate. Thus, it is useful authority on the best‑interests standard, but it does not support the specific proposition that the current arrangement endangers Samantha’s safety or emotional well‑being.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2013Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The standard for modification of custody orders in Massachusetts requires a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since the entry of the prior judgment and that the modification is in the **best interests of the child.** (*See* **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28**; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981)*.)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly interprets and applies M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, stating that a judgment modifying custody must be based on a “material and substantial change in circumstances” since the prior custody order and that the modification must be necessary in the child’s best interests. The court reverses the custody modification precisely because no such material and substantial change was shown and because the best‑interests standard was not properly satisfied, directly aligning with the claimed proposition.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: The standard for modification of custody orders in Massachusetts requires a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since the entry of the prior judgment and that the modification is in the **best interests of the child.** (*See* **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28**; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981)*.)
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion clearly states that to modify a judgment for alimony or child support the petitioner must show a “material change of circumstances” since the earlier judgment, but it does not articulate or apply a distinct ‘best interests of the child’ standard for modification. Its discussion of modification focuses on the obligor’s ability to pay and related financial circumstances, not on custody or best-interest analysis. Thus, Schuler supports only the first part of the proposition (material change in circumstances), not the full combined standard including best interests of the child for custody orders.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28 ….”}

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the **paramount concern of the court is the welfare and best interests of the child.** (*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)*.)
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in custody matters the governing and dominating principle is the welfare of the child, both as a matter of law and humanity, and that the child’s happiness and welfare are the controlling consideration. The court applies this best-interests standard to affirm the custody award, making the case direct authority for the proposition that the paramount concern is the child’s welfare and best interests under Massachusetts law.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the **paramount concern of the court is the welfare and best interests of the child.** (*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)*.)
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly traces the history of the Massachusetts custody standard and reaffirms that the ‘best interests of the child’ is the controlling and paramount consideration in custody determinations. It quotes earlier cases for the proposition that the child’s welfare and best interests are paramount, and then applies that standard directly to the custody dispute in this case. Thus, it clearly supports the cited proposition about Massachusetts law’s paramount concern being the child’s welfare and best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)… Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962), quoting Erickson v. Raspperry, 320 Mass. 333, 335 (1946) (‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Where a parent’s medical condition or physical incapacity materially affects the child’s safety, modification of custodial arrangements may be appropriate. (*See* *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)*.)
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case focused on the best‑interests standard where parents share joint physical custody. The opinion does not involve or discuss a parent’s medical condition or physical incapacity, nor does it address modification of custody on that basis. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition that a parent’s medical condition or physical incapacity affecting child safety may warrant modification of custody; that principle comes from Rolde, not Mason.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The judge made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests, that potential misconduct by other siblings in the mother’s household weighed against increased physical custody by the mother, and that any financial or other advantage of the move to the mother was unclear. From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Where a parent’s medical condition or physical incapacity materially affects the child’s safety, modification of custodial arrangements may be appropriate. (*See* *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)*.)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde v. Rolde does not discuss a parent’s medical condition or physical incapacity as a basis for modifying custody or affecting the child’s safety. The custody analysis focuses on parental antagonism, inability to cooperate, primary caretaker status, and differences in child‑rearing philosophy, not on any health‑related limitations of either parent. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a parent’s medical condition or physical incapacity may justify modification of custodial arrangements.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children. Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing… an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.”}

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: The Court has consistently held that **changes affecting a parent's ability to provide day‑to‑day physical care** constitute material changes warranting modification when such change impacts a child’s environment and stability. (*See* *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981); *White v. LaBarge*, 490 Mass. 911 (2022)*.)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: Hale is a removal case, not a modification-of-custody case, and it does not articulate any rule about what constitutes a material change in circumstances warranting modification. The opinion focuses on how to assess the best interests of the child when a custodial parent seeks to relocate, emphasizing the custodial parent’s well‑being and potential changes in visitation patterns, not changes in the parent’s ability to provide day‑to‑day care as a trigger for modification. Thus it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole, or the emotional costs of forcing a stressful family and career choice, if such be the case, on the parent having the primary responsibility for the day-to-day care of the children.”

White v. LaBarge, 490 Mass. 911 (2022).proposition: The Court has consistently held that **changes affecting a parent's ability to provide day‑to‑day physical care** constitute material changes warranting modification when such change impacts a child’s environment and stability. (*See* *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981); *White v. LaBarge*, 490 Mass. 911 (2022)*.)

Bouchie v. Murray, 376 Mass. 524 (1978).proposition:
The modification sought accords with the statutory and case‑law framework, including:  
   - **M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31** (modification and custody standards)  
   - **M.G.L. c. 215, § 6** (equity jurisdiction of the Probate and Family Court)  
   - *Bouchie v. Murray*, 376 Mass. 524 (1978) (best interests paramount).  
   - *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) (child’s welfare governs custody decisions).  
   - *Macri v. Macri*, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2019) (health and home stability can warrant modification).
Bouchie v. Murray, 376 Mass. 524 (1978).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Bouchie v. Murray addresses evidentiary issues concerning the admissibility of hospital records under G.L. c. 233, § 79, not custody, modification, or the best‑interests standard. It does not discuss M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 or 31, c. 215, § 6, or any principle that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody or modification proceedings. Thus, as used here, the citation does not support the asserted proposition.
Bouchie v. Murray, 376 Mass. 524 (1978).relevant_excerpt: "Our hospital records statute, G. L. c. 233, § 79, is separate from our general business records statute, G. L. c. 233, § 78. … In particular, our hospital records statute ‘in effect provides an exception to the hearsay rule’ for facts that ‘pertain to treatment and medical history.’ … In my view the reliability of statements covered by the statute is left to the discretion of the trial judge by the explicit words of the statute."

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition:
The modification sought accords with the statutory and case‑law framework, including:  
   - **M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31** (modification and custody standards)  
   - **M.G.L. c. 215, § 6** (equity jurisdiction of the Probate and Family Court)  
   - *Bouchie v. Murray*, 376 Mass. 524 (1978) (best interests paramount).  
   - *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) (child’s welfare governs custody decisions).  
   - *Macri v. Macri*, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2019) (health and home stability can warrant modification).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The proposition cites Hunter v. Rose specifically for the principle that a child’s welfare or best interests govern custody decisions. In this opinion, the SJC explicitly reiterates that in custody matters the “touchstone inquiry” is what is best for the child, applies G.L. c. 208, § 31, and affirms a custody order based on a detailed best‑interests analysis. Thus, Hunter v. Rose directly supports the claimed proposition about the governing standard in custody determinations within the statutory framework referenced, even though it is not itself a modification case.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child”…. The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. … The judge has discretion when awarding custody of a child to which we give ‘substantial deference.’”

Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2.raw_text: Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2019)
Macri v. Macri, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2.proposition:
The modification sought accords with the statutory and case‑law framework, including:  
   - **M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31** (modification and custody standards)  
   - **M.G.L. c. 215, § 6** (equity jurisdiction of the Probate and Family Court)  
   - *Bouchie v. Murray*, 376 Mass. 524 (1978) (best interests paramount).  
   - *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) (child’s welfare governs custody decisions).  
   - *Macri v. Macri*, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2019) (health and home stability can warrant modification).
